answers: phototaxis [do not accept or prompt on phototropism]
parts: Name this process in which an organism moves towards or away from a source of light. This behavior is exhibited by fruit flies and moths, which fly using transverse orientation.

The sensation of light during Chlamydomonas phototaxis is controlled by the "channel" form of these proteins. Another one of these proteins activates the G-protein transducin and is found in rod cells.
The absorption of light by channelrhodopsin isomerizes this molecule from its all-trans form to its 13-cis form. This vitamin created from beta-carotene is essential to human vision.

answers: John Cage [or John Milton Cage Jr.]
parts: Identify this avant-garde composer fond of micropolyphony, also known for works like the anti-anti-opera, Le Grand Macabre.

“The Devil’s Staircase” and “Autumn in Warsaw” are two of 18 pieces in this genre composed by Ligeti between 1985 and 2001. Carl Czerny (“CHAIR-nee”) collected his many pieces in this genre in books such as The School of Velocity.

Ligeti’s The Future of Music, where he simply wrote the words “Crescendo,” “piu forte,” and “Silence” on a blackboard is often compared to this composer’s 4'33" (“four minutes, thirty-three seconds”).

answers: USS Bunker Hill [accept Battle of Bunker's Hill or Battle of Breed’s Hill] (The order was “don’t fire until you see the whites of their eyes.”)
parts: Identify this Japanese term for a suicide tactic used by Japan’s pilots late in the war.

The British used the naval version of these planes to defend against kamikaze attacks. These single-seater fighter planes designed by R. J. Mitchell had a starring role in the Battle of Britain alongside the Hawker Hurricane.

Over 300 American sailors died in the dual kamikaze attacks on this ship during the Battle of Okinawa. This ship was named for a 1775 battle where American commander William Prescott gave a famous order.

answers: Gordon Parks [or Gordon Roger Alexander Buchanan Parks]
parts: Name this Harlem-based photographer who depicted a Black cleaning lady holding a mop and a broom in front of the American flag. He also directed The Learning Tree and Shaft.
Parks' Shaft jump-started this genre of films which focused on issues such as racial profiling. This film genre is named for appealing to African Americans.

Gordon Parks was the first Black staff photographer for this now-defunct American photojournalism magazine. On most covers, this non-TIME magazine's four-letter name was printed in white letters in a red box on top of a full-page photo.

answers: petroglyphs [accept Petroglyph National Monument; prompt on rock art; do not accept or prompt on “geoglyphs”]
GPS [or Global Positioning System; or RNSS; or Radionavigation-satellite service; or GNSS; or global navigation satellite system; accept handheld GPS receivers; prompt on smart phones or satnav]
Lidar [or LADAR; prompt on 3D laser scanning]
parts: The Starry Night Pro app helped decipher "lost" examples of these images made by the Slakaiya people in California. Thousands of these images were carved by the Pueblo people onto West Mesa at a namesake National Monument in New Mexico.
Since the 1980s, archaeologists have widely used this technology to precisely mark sites. This geolocation technology relies on atomic clocks in satellites.
A helicopter equipped with this map-making technology helped archaeologists find the lost city of Mahendraparvata in Cambodia. Velodyne makes high-end versions of this tech for self-driving cars.

answers: Gabriele d’Annunzio [or Gabriele D’Annunzio, Prince of Montenevoso]
parts: Name this Italian decadent author whose “Novels of the Rose” include The Triumph of Death. He was called “The Poet” during his proto-fascist rule of the Republic of Fiume (“FYOO-may”).

D’Annunzio’s protagonists often embody this Nietzschean archetype of an “artist-tyrant.” Walter Kaufmann critiqued old translations of Thus Spake Zarathustra for associating this archetype with a comic book character born Kal-El.
In a 1901 tragedy by d’Annunzio, this character is killed in bed by her husband Giovanni Malatesta. As in the fifth canto of The Inferno, she falls in love with Giovanni’s younger brother Paolo.

answers: liberation theology [or teología de la liberación]
parts: Name this agricultural commune in Guyana that was established by the Peoples Temple, a new religious movement.
The Peoples Temple, which carried out the Jonestown massacre, was founded in this state. Junípero Serra, canonized by Pope Francis in 2015, founded several Spanish missions in this western state.
Jim Jones preached an “apostolic socialism” influenced by this movement, which the Peruvian priest Gustavo Gutiérrez helped establish. This movement advocates a “preferential option for the poor.”
Name this amino acid which typically has a positive charge due to its pKa (“P-K-A”) of about 6. This amino acid’s side chain is one of several that can be detected by absorbance at 280 nanometers.

The active site of chymotrypsin (“kye-mo-TRIP-sin”) contains a dedicated hole for a tetrahedral anion of this element formed as an intermediate. This element is the nucleophile in serine and threonine proteases and is found alongside nitrogen and carbon in peptide bonds.
The cleavage of peptide bonds is a form of “-lysis” named for this molecule, which makes up the majority of the cytosol.

answers: Wilson [accept Frank Wilson or August Wilson] (That is the Pittsburgh Cycle.)
parts: Name this director whose Mercury Theatre went "on the air" for its many acclaimed radio dramas.

The first production for the Negro Theatre Unit was Walk Together, Children by a playwright with this surname. A later playwright with this surname wrote a "cycle" of ten plays, one for each decade of the 20th century.
The Negro Theater Unit premiered those plays at the Lafayette Theater in this New York neighborhood, where writer Langston Hughes was part of a 1920s literary "Renaissance."

answers: Manzanar War Relocation Center [accept Manzanar National Historic Site or Manzanar Concentration Camp or Manzanar Internment Camp]
parts: Identify this Constitutionally-mandated information-gathering procedure conducted every ten years.

During World War II, census records were used to carry out the forced internment of Japanese-Americans, like those sent to this “Relocation Center” near Lone Pine, California, now a national historic site.
In this decade, the Johnson-Reed Immigration Act used decades-old census data for quotas to keep out “beaten men from beaten races.”

answers: Eugène de Rastignac (“oo-ZHEN duh ross-teen-YAHK”) [or Eugène de Rastignac]
parts: Parisians went wild for works in this medium, invented in Scotland by Robert Barker. Today, most phones can take these types of wide-angle, landscape-format photos by stitching together individual images.

This artist installed the first diorama in the Place du Château-d’Eau (“plahss doo sha-toh-DOH”) in 1822. He invented an early form of photography noted for sharp images that was exposed onto a silver-plated sheet.
Honore de Balzac satirized the mania for all things “rama” in his novel Le Père Goriot (“luh PAIR gor-YO”), which introduced this law student, now a French term for any sort of social climber.

answers: Fulani [accept Fule or Fulbe or Peul or Fallata or Fulah]
parts: Name this ethnic group related to the Hausa which formed the Sokoto Caliphate under their leader Usman dan Fodio. Nana Asma’u, a member of this ethnicity, organized jajis to educate women in the Sokoto Caliphate.
Nana Asma’u’s poetry popularized this state religion of the Sokoto Caliphate in Hausaland. The Fulani, who practiced this religion, fought several jihads in the 19th century.
During Fulani hegemony, many “Moroccan” examples of this good were actually produced in Kano. The tanneries that made this good were especially smelly places.
Give this theory that predicts the formation of composite bosons with lower energy than the Fermi energy of a material.

BCS microscopically models this phenomenon in which a material’s resistance vanishes under a certain temperature. Materials exhibiting this phenomenon expel their magnetic fields in the Meissner effect.
Practical “high-temperature” superconductors would have to have critical temperatures above 77 kelvins, the boiling point of this widely available coolant.

answers: Castor AND Pollux [or the Dioscuri; or Tyndaridae or Tyndarids; or Gemini]
Ashwin twins [or Ashvins; or Ashwini Kumaras; or Asvins]
parts: Name these semi-divine figures born from golden eggs laid by Leda. These people abducted Phoebe and Hilaeira, the daughters of Leucippus.
Castor and Pollux were born alongside Helen and this woman. After the Trojan War ends, she helps her lover Aegisthus kill her husband Agamemnon.

Castor and Pollux are the Greek version of the Proto-Indo-European divine twins mytheme, also represented by these Vedic brothers who ride their horses at sunrise and sunset. These twin medicine gods do not have separate names in the Rigveda.
Name this artist who painted a scientist recreating a demonstration by Robert Boyle in his painting An Experiment on a Bird in the Air Pump.
Joseph Wright of Derby was known for employing this technique, whose name combines two Italian words. Tenebrism is an especially pronounced form of this technique.
Many paintings that employ chiaroscuro use these objects as their sole light source. Barry Lyndon was shot with special lenses in order to capture the low-key lighting produced by these objects.

answers: Virginia Woolf [or Adeline Virginia Woolf; or Virginia Stephen]
Shakespeare [accept William Shakespeare or Judith Shakespeare]
Russian (Torrents of Spring is by Turgenev.)
parts: Name this author who intercut scenes of a snail crawling through a flower bed in between moments in the lives of various passersby in the story “Kew Gardens.”

Virginia Woolf’s essay “A Room of One's Own" imagines how Judith, a fictional author with this surname, is unable to pursue writing, unlike her brother. A real author with this last name wrote The Winter’s Tale.
Woolf’s essay “Modern Fiction” praises the style of a story in this language translated into English by Constance Garnett. Garnett also translated Torrents of Spring from this language.
In 2019, most KaiOS phones were sold in this country, where Reliance Industries has subsidized extremely cheap data plans. This country banned TikTok in June 2020 during a spat with China.

KaiOS grew out of a failed effort by this non-profit to build an open-source phone operating system. In 2014, Brendan Eich was forced out of this non-profit for opposing a California gay marriage law.
This South Korean company is the main developer of the Linux-based Tizen operating system, which powers its Galaxy Gear line of smartwatches.

answers: The Golden Ass [or the Metamorphoses of Apuleius; or asinus aureus]
parts: Give the true name of this character whom Lucius addresses as Campensis. She instructs him to eat a crown of roses to return to human form.
Isis heals Lucius in this book by Apuleius, which contains the only ancient narrative of the Cupid and Psyche myth.
Apuleius’s The Golden Ass is the only fully-preserved Latin work in this genre of long prose fiction, to which the Satyricon also belongs.

answers: William [accept William the Silent or William I or William III]
Anabaptists [prompt on Christians or Protestants; do not accept or prompt on “Amish” or “Mennonites”]
parts: Name this Dutch city that was relieved by the Sea Beggar navy after the dikes were cut in 1574. Before coming to America, the Pilgrims lived in this city.
The University of Leiden was founded by the first stadtholder of this name, known as the Silent. A stadtholder of this name ruled England with his wife Mary after the Glorious Revolution.
A 1648 treaty signed in Munster granted Dutch Independence. Munster was earlier a refuge for members of this persecuted religious group whose splinter groups included the Hutterites.

answers: impurities [accept dopants or doping agents; prompt on crystallographic defects]
calcite [prompt on limestone or chalk; anti-prompt on calcium carbonate or CaCO3]
parts: Corundum defines 9 on the Mohs scale, but the blue color of sapphires is caused by the intense transitions between metal ion examples of these entities in the crystal lattice.
The 7.5 Mohs rating of zircon has allowed specific crystals to have values of this quantity that exceed 4.4 billion years, measured using the long half-life of uranium as it decays to lead.

Samples of aragonite will slowly transform into this more stable polymorph, which is a measly 3 on the Mohs scale. This carbonate mineral is very susceptible to chemical weathering, which can form karst landscapes.

answers: circle [accept circle of fifths or circle of fourths]
Prometheus: The Poem of Fire [accept Prometheus chord]
parts: Name this composer whose interest in theosophy may have influenced his synesthesia. He composed Mysterium, a composition to be played in the Himalayas to somehow bring about the apocalypse.

Some scholars believe that Scriabin did not experience synesthesia, as he color-coded a diagram of this shape with consecutive notes separated by a fifth such that the notes form the visible spectrum.
The clavier à lumières is used in this Scriabin “Poem of Fire.” Its namesake opening chord is more often called the mystic chord.
